p: Higher temperatures, however, cause greater evapotranspiration, leading to reduced water availability, which alone can increase the probability of drought stress (Beniston, 2003). Regional scenarios on precipitation change are inconsistent; however, projections for central Europe show that mean precipitation tends to decrease in summer and increase in winter (Schmidli et al., 2007), with increasingly more rain instead of snow in mountainous regions (Steger et al., 2013). Snow cover is generally declining in the Alps, although patterns of changes in the amount of snowfall are also rather patchy (Gobiet et al., 2014). Moreover, the significant trend towards a longer annual snow‐free period has been shown to be consistent with reported trends of longer growing seasons (Dye, 2002; Giménez‐Benavides et al., 2007). Combined effects of higher temperatures and concomitant drier conditions can result in strong transforming forces on cold‐adapted plant communities (Lesica, 2014), which was also experimentally confirmed (De Boeck et al., 2016).
